title: 111_hr3905
content: The "Estate Tax Relief Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. It includes the restoration of the estate tax and the repeal of carryover basis. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is repealed, including specific provisions related to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The sunset provision does not apply after December 31, 2010, except for title V. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is repealed, with specific provisions related to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 901 is amended to remove references to estates, gifts, and transfers. SEC. 3. Increase in unified credit against the estate tax. The table in subsection (c) of section 2010 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the applicable credit amount. The estate tax exclusion amounts for decedents dying from 2009 to 2019 or later are as follows: $3,500,000 in 2009, $3,650,000 in 2010, $3,800,000 in 2011, $3,950,000 in 2012, $4,100,000 in 2013, $4,250,000 in 2014, $4,400,000 in 2015, $4,550,000 in 2016, $4,700,000 in 2017, $4,850,000 in 2018, and $5,000,000 in 2019 or thereafter. In 2019 or later, the estate tax exclusion amount is $5,000,000 and will be adjusted for inflation for decedents dying in calendar years after 2019. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying, and gifts made, after December 31, 2008. If any increase determined is not a multiple of $10,000, it shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. SEC. 4. Coordinated reduction in maximum rate of tax with termination of deduction for state death taxes. The table in section 2001(c)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to phase in the reduction in maximum rate. The maximum estate tax rate has been gradually reduced from 45 percent in 2009 to 35 percent in 2019 and beyond. Amendments have been made to the Internal Revenue Code to reflect these changes. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to the deduction for State death taxes, with a phaseout beginning after December 31, 2008. The maximum estate tax rate has decreased from 45 percent in 2009 to 35 percent in 2019 and beyond. The applicable percentage for determining deductions is based on a table provided in the Internal Revenue Code. The applicable percentage for tax deductions based on calendar year varies from 100 percent in 2009 to 0 percent in 2019 and thereafter. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after December 31, 2008.
